revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2020}} {{other uses}} [[File:NoGodsNoMasters.jpg|alt=Anarchists carrying a banner|right|thumb|Anarchists marching with the 'No Gods, No Masters' slogan on a banner]]
'''No gods, no masters''' is an anarchist and labour slogan. It has been in common use by anarchists in England since the late 19th century. The journal ''[[Commonweal (newspaper)|Commonweal]]'', for instance, includes an article by [[John Creaghe]] from Sheffield in which he records that the ''[[Sheffield Telegraph]]'' newspaper 'was furious when it found we were Anarchists with "Neither God nor Master" for our motto' (11 July 1891, p. 76). An early 20th century usage is evident in a pamphlet handed out by the [[Industrial Workers of the World]] during the [[1912 Lawrence Textile Strike]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://wyatt.elasticbeanstalk.com/mep/MS/xml/mshist.html |title=mshist |publisher=Wyatt.elasticbeanstalk.com |date=5 January 1916 |accessdate=11 June 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304074925/http://wyatt.elasticbeanstalk.com/mep/MS/xml/mshist.html |archive-date=4 March 2016 |url-status=dead }}</ref> The phrase is derived from the French slogan "''Ni dieu ni maître''!" (literally 'Neither god nor master') coined by the [[socialist]] [[Louis Auguste Blanqui]] in 1880, when he published a journal by that name.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://radicalreference.info/node/605 |title=Question: origin of the slogan "ni dieu ni maître" | Radical Reference |publisher=Radicalreference.info |date= |accessdate=11 June 2012}}</ref>{{unreliable source?|certain=y|reason=Message boards are not reliable sources.|date=April 2018}} In [[Joseph Conrad]]'s novel ''[[The Secret Agent]]'', first published in 1907, the anarchist character The Professor says: "My device is: No God! No master."<ref>(Joseph Conrad, The Secret Agent, Pan Classics, 1975 edition, p. 228)</ref>
==Uses== [[File:The Woman Rebel, March 1914, Vol 1, No. 1.gif|thumb|[[Margaret Sanger]]'s feminist pamphlet used the slogan as a subtitle in 1914.]]
Its first use can be traced back to the French journal Ni Dieu ni maître, published in 1880 by Auguste Blanqui. The French phrase appears twice in [[Friedrich Nietzsche]]'s 1886 work ''[[Beyond Good and Evil]]''. It appears first in Section 22, in a critique of the notion that nature dictates a morality of equality before the law. It appears again in section 202 where he identifies it with the anarchists and as indicative of their "herd" mentality, which he is criticizing.<ref>{{cite web|title=Friedrich Nietzsche, Beyond Good and Evil|url=http://records.viu.ca/~johnstoi/nietzsche/beyondgoodandevil5.htm |date=February 2009 |accessdate=12 August 2012}}</ref> It is also the inspiration behind English poet [[A.E. Housman]]'s "The laws of God, the laws of man", which was published in 1922 in his final collection, ''[[Last Poems]]''. The poem effectively dramatises the psychological urge behind the saying, but also ends with a reflection on the impracticality criticism often levelled at anarchist philosophy.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.gutenberg.org/files/7848/7848-h/7848-h.htm#link2H_4_0012|title=The laws of god, the laws of man|date= |accessdate=16 September 2016}}</ref>
===Feminist usage=== In 1914, [[Margaret Sanger]] launched ''The Woman Rebel'', an eight-page monthly newsletter which promoted contraception using the slogan "No Gods, No Masters". Sanger insisted that every woman was the mistress of her own body.<ref>{{cite web|title="No Gods, No Masters": Margaret Sanger on Birth Control|url=http://historymatters.gmu.edu/d/5084/|publisher=gmu.edu|accessdate=5 June 2012}}</ref>
''Women without superstition: No gods – No Masters!'' by [[Annie Laurie Gaylor]] is a collection of writings by women [[Freethought|freethinkers]] during the 19th and 20th century.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=8P5JAAAAIBAJ&sjid=BR4NAAAAIBAJ&pg=2199,3143875&dq=women-without-superstition&hl=en |title=The Michigan Daily – Google News Archive |date= |accessdate=18 June 2012}}</ref>
===Contemporary usage=== Today the slogan continues to find use in anarchist politics. An anthology of anarchist writing was collected under the title "No Gods, No Masters: An Anthology of Anarchism".<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books/about/No_Gods_No_Masters.html?id=g4YncZ8MgRsC |title=No Gods, No Masters – Daniel Guérin – Google Books |via=[[Google Books]]|accessdate=11 June 2012|isbn=9781904859253 |last1=Guérin |first1=Daniel |year=2005 }}</ref>
The slogan has also found use in musical cultures, largely associated with the [[Punk subculture|punk]] movement. But it was first used in the French [[chanson]] field, by the anarchist poet and singer-songwriter [[Léo Ferré]] who released the song "Ni Dieu ni maître" on an EP in 1965.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/L%C3%A9o-Ferr%C3%A9-Ni-Dieu-Ni-Ma%C3%AEtre/release/1475925|title=Léo Ferré – Ni Dieu Ni Maître|publisher=}}</ref> This song, metaphorically depicting the French death penalty procedure, ends with these verses: "This slogan that breaks all the rules / Made for the benefit of fools / Rejecting all authority / Unless respecting liberty / This principle of human rights / I recommend it for your fights / We shall proclaim it to the last / No God no master!".
The slogan was also chosen as a song title by the English crust punk/heavy metal band [[Amebix]] on their EP ''[[Who's the Enemy]]'',<ref>{{cite web|title=AMEBIX- Who's the Enemy 7"EP (Spiderleg Records, UK, 1982)|url=http://www.goodbadmusic.com/2007/06/17/amebix-whos-the-enemy-7ep-spiderleg-records-uk-1982/|publisher=goodbadmusic.com|accessdate=5 June 2012}}</ref> Swedish death metal band [[Arch Enemy]] on their album ''[[Khaos Legions]]'',<ref>{{cite web|title=Arch Enemy official site|url=http://archenemy.net/2011/index.php?go=music|publisher=Arch Enemy|accessdate=5 June 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140202230214/http://archenemy.net/2011/index.php?go=music|archive-date=2 February 2014|url-status=dead}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Khaos Legions review|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/khaos-legions-mw0002143136|publisher=allmusic.com|accessdate=5 June 2012}}</ref> Luxembourgish neofolk/martial band [[Rome (band)|Rome]] on their album ''Confessions D'Un Voleur D'Ames''<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.discogs.com/Rome-Confessions-DUn-Voleur-DAmes/master/314074|title=Rome (4) – Confessions D'Un Voleur D'Ames|website=Discogs|language=en|access-date=31 August 2017}}</ref>'','' and Chicago-based hardcore band [[Harm's Way (band)|Harm's Way]], who released an EP entitled ''No Gods, No Masters'' in 2010.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.closedcasketactivities.com/site/releases/cca017/|title=Closed Casket Activities " Harm's Way – No Gods No Masters|publisher=|access-date=29 August 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180521091349/http://closedcasketactivities.com/site/releases/cca017/|archive-date=21 May 2018|url-status=dead}}</ref> The slogan is used as the main chorus in the song "Religious Cancer" by [[Nailbomb]] on their album ''[[Point Blank (Nailbomb album)|Point Blank]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://play.google.com/music/preview/Twx4speo6fncejziytqa2tmq6wm?lyrics=1&pcampaignid=kp-lyrics|title=Religious Cancer Lyrics at Google Play Music}}</ref>
Canadian female punk band [[Pantychrist]] released their song "No Gods No Masters"<ref>{{cite web|title=Pantychrist Bandcamp|url=https://pantychrist.bandcamp.com/track/no-gods-no-masters|publisher=Pantychrist|accessdate=24 November 2018}}</ref> in 2014 with lyrics espousing the pro-feminist usage of the phrase that was used as the byline of the 1914 [[Margaret Sanger]] newsletter ''The Woman Rebel''.
The slogan was rephrased as ''[[No Gods, No Managers]]'', as an album title by American crack rock steady band [[Choking Victim]].<ref name="amazon1">{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.ca/No-Gods-Managers-Choking-Victim/dp/B000028DFU |title=No Gods/No Managers: Choking Victim: Amazon.ca: Music |publisher=Amazon.ca |date= |accessdate=11 June 2012}}</ref>
Some [[Anarchism and religion|religious anarchists]], who combine neopagan religiosity and anarchist ideas, use a modified version: "Many Gods, No masters".
==See also== {{Sister project links|wikt=no|q=no|voy=no|n=no|v=no|b=no|s=no|d=Q50096736|c=Category:No gods, no masters}} {{Portal|Anarchism|Society}} * [[Anarchism and religion]] * [[An injury to one is an injury to all]] * ''[[No God, No Master]]'', a 2014 film based on the First Red Scare. * [[Question authority]]
